citeinfo.origin: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), Alaska Fisheries Science Center (AFSC)
citeinfo.title: Gulf of Alaska Shelf ECOPATH Model

descript.abstract: Throughout the 1990s, there have been extensive commercial fisheries in the Gulf of Alaska for groundfish, as well as crab, herring, halibut, and salmon. Removals of both the target species and bycatch by these (and historical) fisheries have been suggested as a possible cause for the decline of the western stock of Stellar sea lions, which are now listed as an endangered species. An ECOPATH/ECOSIM model for the Gulf of Alaska could test the hypothesis that fishery removals of groundfish and bycatch during the 1990s have contributed to the continued decline of Steller sea lions. In addition, a community restructuring in which shrimp populations declined dramatically and commercial fish populations increased between the 1960s and the 1990s may have occurred, according to small mesh trawl surveys conducted by National Marine Fisheries Service and Alaska Department of Fish & Game. An additional hypothesis, which could be tested with this model, is that this trophic reorganization has had a negative impact on marine mammal and bird populations in the Gulf of Alaska. Finally, the effects on an apparent increase in shark populations on their prey and the relative importance of these effects in the whole system could be evaluated with an ECOPATH model.
descript.purpose: To investigate Steller sea lion population decline.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system.
